content.text: Define _density
Explain how the difference in the densities of solids, liquids and gases may be related to the spacing of their molecules
Calculate the density, in \(\mathrm{kgm}^{- 3}\), of the material from which the paving slab is made
density = .........$\mathrm{kgm}^{- 3}$
Calculate the maximum pressure a slab could exert on the ground when resting on one of its surfaces
pressure = .........$Pa$
A paving slab has a mass of \(68\mathrm{kg}\) and dimensions \(50\mathrm{mm}\times 600\mathrm{mm}\times 900\mathrm{mm}\)
Define the torque of a couple
Calculate the torque on the rod produced by ropes A and B
torque = .........Nm
Discuss, briefly, whether the rod is in equilibrium
A uniform rod of length \(1.5 \text{m}\) and weight \(2.4 \text{N}\) is shown in Fig. 2.1
The rod is supported on a pin passing through a hole in its centre. Ropes A and B provide equal and opposite forces of 8.0N
Calculate the tension in rope B
tension in B = .........N
Calculate the tension in rope A
tension in A = .........N
The rod in **(b)** is removed from the pin and supported by ropes A and B, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Rope A is now at point P 0.30m from one end of the rod and rope B is at the other end
its horizontal component of velocity,
horizontal component of velocity = .........$m s^{-1}$
its vertical component of velocity
vertical component of velocity = .........$m s^{-1}$
For the ball at S, calculate
calculate the vertical height gained by the ball when it travels from S to P,
show that the time taken for the ball to travel from S to P is \(1.33 \text{s}\),
show that the velocity of the ball immediately after rebounding from the wall is about \(4.6 \text{m s}^{-1}\)

The horizontal distance from S to the wall is \(9.95 \text{m}\). The ball hits the wall at P with a velocity that is at right angles to the wall. The ball rebounds to a point F that is \(6.15 \text{m}\) from the wall
Using your answers in **(a)**,
Calculate the change in momentum of the ball as it rebounds from the wall
change in momentum = .........$N$ s
State and explain whether the collision is elastic or inelastic
The mass of the ball is \(60 \times 10^{-3} \text{kg}\)
A ball is thrown against a vertical wall. The path of the ball is shown in Fig. 3.1
The ball is thrown from S with an initial velocity of \(15.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at \(60.0^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Assume that air resistance is negligible
Distinguish between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy

A body of mass \(m\) moves vertically through a distance \(h\) near the Earth's surface. Use the defining equation for work done to derive an expression for the gravitational potential energy change of the body
Show that the speed of the water as it reaches the wheel is \(15\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\)

The rotating water wheel is used to produce \(110\mathrm{kW}\) of electrical power. Calculate the mass of water flowing per second through the wheel, assuming that the production of electric energy from the kinetic energy of the water is \(25\%\) efficient
For
Examiner's
Use
mass of water per second = .........kgs\(^{- 1}\)
Water flows down a stream from a reservoir and then causes a water wheel to rotate, as shown in Fig. 4.1

As the water falls through a vertical height of \(120\mathrm{m}\), gravitational potential energy is converted to different forms of energy, including kinetic energy of the water. At the water wheel, the kinetic energy of the water is only \(10\%\) of its gravitational potential energy at the reservoir
Define the \(ohm\)
Determine the SI base units of **resistivity**
base units of resistivity = .........
Calculate the resistivity of the metal wire
resistivity = .........
The resistance of R may be varied between 0 and 1500 \(\Omega\)
Calculate the maximum potential difference (p.d.) and minimum p.d. possible across the wire
Calculate the power transformed in the wire when the potential difference across the wire is 2.0V
A cell of e.m.f. \(2.0\mathrm{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected to a variable resistor R and a metal wire, as shown in Fig. 5.1
The wire is \(900\mathrm{mm}\) long and has an area of cross-section of \(1.3\times 10^{-7}\mathrm{m}^2\). The resistance of the wire is \(3.4\Omega\)
zero resistance,
infinite resistance
Resistance R in (c) is now replaced with a different variable resistor Q. State the power transformed in Q, for Q having
State Hooke's law
Describe the meaning of _elastic limit_
Calculate the spring constant \(k_{\mathrm{A}}\) for spring A
Calculate the work done in extending the spring with a force of 6.4 N
work done = .........J
The variation with extension \(x\) of the force \(F\) for a spring A is shown in Fig. 6.1
The point L on the graph is the elastic limit of the spring
the total extension,
extension = .........m
the spring constant
spring constant = .........N m
A second spring B of spring constant \(2k_{\mathrm{A}}\) is now joined to spring A, as shown in Fig. 6.2
A force of 6.4 N extends the combination of springs
For the combination of springs, calculate

Explain the term isotope
In a nuclear reaction, proton number and neutron number are conserved. Other than proton number and neutron number, state a quantity that is conserved in a nuclear reaction
